I did my first live performance today. It was fairly simple but it sucked. I knew it sucked when I was doing it, and the more times I listen to the recording, the more flaws I notice. I got too emotional and accidentally sped up the tempo at one point. The mic was too quiet. All the techniques I learned headed straight out. The entire thing was awkward. I'm pretty sure I'll do more live performances in the future, but right now I just want to erase this from my memory, but I can't. The anxiety is killing me right now. Has this happened to you before? Do you have any advices on coping with it?

i had just thrust myself into a brand new schedule, so i knew i would be extremely tight on time for all parts of the process. i took a walk to try to relax and prepare for the insanity, and i allowed my mind to casually try to recall from memory if there are any songs which might stand out as good choices. 'special sandals' (which was only 8 bars at the time) seemed to cross my mind, because it's one that i'd been fond of for the past couple years since writing. it's one of the ones that keeps persistently popping into my head, in general. so i thought of that one. Normally i would have probably rejected that one on the basis of 'sandals' being too iffy and weird and possibly not strong. Or the fact that it was only 8 bars and i might have preferred to pick something that was a little further along. However, this being a brand new schedule, it seemed like the perfect sort of carefree vibe to pick that one. Of course, being who i am, i had to insist on going through the list properly, so i did. it looks like i came up with 10 finalists, including special sandals. it turns out, sandals was still feeling favored, and got extra points for having visited me earlier on the walk
What is the tempo of your next song
What's the breakdown for how much of new canaan was written prior to the trip, en route to new canaan, in new canaan, on the return trip home, and at home after the trip?

none of it was written before the trip. during the trip, (may 15, 2009) this entire version was written ((ref: https://billwurtz.com/newcanaan-p1.jpg"target="_blank">page 1 and (ref: https://billwurtz.com/newcanaan-p2.jpg"target=)_blank)page 2). the part about harlem was written while the train was stopped at the 125 street stop (harlem). that's where the idea came from. By the time i got to new canaan i feel like i had likely made it to at least the end of the chorus ('every word i say is true'). Some of the next parts were written at the outdoor tables at starbucks, just next to the train station in new canaan. i took a brief walk for a few blocks and may have worked on the last chorus (grey) while waiting for the train and/or on the way back. 
On nov 6, 2012, i made some clarifications to the melody and chords. Decided on the key of D. Did some re-writes, such as "12 figure" instead of 7 figure, and i also came up with the 'license plates' line to replace the line that was there before. The entire starbucks stanza was re-written to be stronger. Also re-wrote the last chorus to be stronger.
on august 9, 2013 some small melody/chord details were clarified/adjusted

In that one song that I forgot the name of it supposedly scrolls through all the possible combinations of 6 letter like it's some base 26 counting system. The thing is that I inspected it came by frame and say that there was the word memory separating huge chunks of the combinations. Are those there to save memory or for some other reason?

to save memory and time in multiple ways. give it a try: try displaying all combinations of 6 letters in alphabetical order. try to do anything with it. try to save it in a file. try to send it to someone. try to depict its entirety on a screen in any way, in any reasonable amount of time and/or at a reasonable frame rate. i think you may be surprised at how astronomically large a quantity we're dealing with

So in one song the lyrics go "Wednesday feels so long ago. I said it three or four songs ago." But going through the catalog of songs 3 or 4 prior to that one I don't hear any references to anything like that. So I was just wondering if it was actually a reference to a previous song or just a series of words that sounded cool together so there they were?

it's a combination of very true sentiments. to quote the relevant parts, it's "hello, it's a tuesday show"..... "i said it 3 or 4 songs ago, IT'S TIME FOR THE SHOW". For a long time now i've expressed intense desire to have a very regular (preferably weekly) release of new material, such as songs/videos. I decided somewhere along the line that i gravitate toward Tuesday as the preferred release date, if and when such a release schedule could be achieved. "said it 3 or 4 songs ago" is quite an understatement actually...... i say it all the time. Not necessarily in songs, but i express this desire constantly, and perhaps i was just using 'songs' as a way to measure time. Like if you are measuring time in Jeopardy episodes, you might say it was 3 or 4 Jeopardys ago, even if the event did not actually occur on Jeopardy. Nonetheless, it wasn't just 3 or 4 songs ago, it seems like a constant desire for the past many years. Anyone who knows me is well aware of my obsession with achieving this kind of regular release schedule, and i've certainly talked about it here. In addition, when it says "it's time for the show", i do recall using that line in an improv at some point, which is posted on this site. So in a way, the line is also a reference to that improv. Which itself is probably yet another reference to my ongoing desire to present a regularly scheduled show of content. ALSO, i probably had in mind that i've used the word "Wednesday" prominently in a song, released in 2015. That's more than 3 or 4 songs ago, but in that sense it would be a hyperbolic estimate. and i'd say that reference is probably only secondary to the reference to the desire for a regular release schedule. Also, to boot, i admit i was thinking the phrase also sounded cool, while also having several different angles of metaphoric truth for me

any significance to endingCorner Store on a bm7 chord other than the "store" closing?It's one of the only songs I can think of that spends so much time in (B) major and then ends on the minor.Awesome work thanks for being a constant source of inspiration.

at the end, you have to consider the B minor in the key of A. so it's like ending on the 2 minor (not 1). The fact that it's the same root as the key of the verse is a coincidence. If i could try to understand why it had to be a 2 there, well, the other choruses use 4 there instead. in those previous choruses, the 4 was a brand new chord. In the final chorus, however, the 4s are blasting strong at the top of each line. so to achieve the same 'new' effect, you'd want to swap the 4 for 2. and when you consider it's the final 'closing' of the store and song, it becomes a no brainer to hunker down on the 2 there. i'm just trying to explain now after the fact, why it happened that way. it reminds me of the ending of "got to know what's going on"

im tryna improve my piano playing... ive delved deeply in theory and am currently learning the confusing world of chord extensions... should i simply learn through a numerical relationship perspective or should i truly take the time to learn all these different chords, harmonies and fingerings in all 12 keys? shortcuts welcome (digital capo??)

oh dear, i've heard about this....... you're probably getting the idea that something 'extends', probably 'up' from the chord. i think i'd like to suggest that you throw that away and instead think about notes extending downward from the melody. for example, if it's the key of C and you have note A in the melody and the chord is Fmaj7, think of A at the top and then E just below and then C, and then way below goes the F. don't forget to always use songs, otherwise things may suffocate

recently almost every chorus/prechorus idea i've been excited about has had a 4 chord under the first bar of it. |4|1|5|6m 5|, |4|6m|5|2m 1|, |4|5|3m|6m|, |4|5|6m|1|, |4|6m|3m|3m|, etc. (i come up with the melody before or at the same time as the chords, so i'm not doing anything chords-first.) i think what appeals to me is that it feels like you're near the base of a mountain, looking up at the top of the mountain. it gives you an itch to climb the mountain. being on the 4 is like having unfinished business,
right

so it's automatic dramatic tension for the rest of the hook to resolve. even in something like a |6m|4|1|5|, i feel like the 6m is forlorn and the 4 is what injects hope into it (noticing the top of the mountain).

the downside is i feel it's making my ideas sound too similar. like i'm making different versions of the same song each time. i would still like to make something you can dance and sing along to, and still have that dramatic tension , but what is another good way to do it without starting on the 4? do i just need to wait for my taste in melodies to change?

rearrange the whole situation. change something even more drastic so you never have to be in that situation. someone probably has asked this before, but when you come up with stuff, where is some of the first parts of the songs you develop them? The melodies, bass lines, chords, etc. And how long does it take you to flesh out majority of a song?

i have no idea what 'fleshing' means, but 99% of the time the song is written in order of time, in the song. so the beginning is written first, then the next part, then the next, etc all the way to the end. I can usually get through the writing of a song in about 1 to 3 days. it's unpredictable because mechanism revolves around imagining new things out of nowhere. there's unfortunately no guaranteed service counter you can go and pick up the next part. you kind of have to just sit around and pray. and the more you can trick yourself into not trying, the better it will go. the most valuable thing you can do to coax the next part into existence is do a clean run through from the beginning, after not hearing it for a while

Hi, I just wanted to say that I am really happy I found out about you and your music. Given everything I've learned about you, you seem to be attempting to convey a special perspective/attitude about things to the world, a perspective that is very important to you because of its sincerity, optimism, power, and profound inspiration. I have not seen many people, if at all, with quite the goal you have, before I found out about you. And that is extremely inspiring and validating to me, because I had often felt like I was the only one who had this special, sincere, optimistic, powerful perspective on things, and who wanted to share this perspective with the world to make the world more open and joyous. I have, like you, found it extraordinary difficult, in fact impossible, to find people who I actually connect with, and I seriously believe it's because nobody quite has the perspective I do on things. Just wanted to tell you about how I think there are people li ke you out there. If my perspective/attitude about things is the same as yours, which I feel like it essentially is, then you can rest assured that there are other people helping share this perspective with everyone. I appreciate the fact that you exist and you are also helping lift up the world this way.

writing is like magic....... no one knows where it comes from. when it comes, it's very very quick. instantaneous.
